ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said doing well with China in trade talks and other countries, while there were separate comments from NEC Director Kudlow that some but not all China tariffs may remain and that US-China trade talks are not time dependent. (Newswires)

China are reportedly offering foreign technology firms better access to China’s fast-growing cloud-computing market according to sources. Furthermore, the reports added that the plan is part of a package of offers on technology-related issues Chinese negotiators are expected to discuss with their US counterparts during high-level meetings scheduled for Friday and under the proposal, foreign providers would be able to own data centers as part of a pilot in a free-trade zone. (WSJ)

  • New Zealand ANZ Consumer Confidence (Mar) M/M 0.8% (Prev. -0.7%)
  • New Zealand Building Consents (Feb) M/M 1.9% (Prev. 16.5%, Rev. 13.6%)

 

UK/EU

UK government source confirmed they were laying a motion to give MPs a vote on the withdrawal agreement only for Friday without the political declaration on the future relationship between the EU and the UK, while a government source said the vote to approve the withdrawal agreement would meet the EU's test to extend A50 to May 22nd and is said to be substantially different to MV3. (Newswires/BBC/Twitter)

UK government ministers privately suggested a general election will be called if Friday's vote is rejected or things "fall apart", according HuffPost's Paul Waugh. Elsewhere, there were comments from House Speaker Bercow that the new government motion meets his tests and only covers withdrawal agreement, while Sun's Tom Newton Dunn reports it will occur at 14:30GMT/10:30EDT. (Newswires/Twitter/Huffington Post)

DUP sources commented that splitting the votes on Brexit withdrawal agreement and political declaration doesn't solve anything. (FT/Twitter)

ECB's Villeroy said that deflationary risks have receded and there is no reason to go more negative on interest rates, while he added that given inflation is still below target, upside shocks are more welcome than downside ones. (Newswires)

FX

SNB's Maechler said CHF remains highly valued and currency remains fragile, while Maechler added that negative rates and currency interventions remains necessary where required. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

US President Trump tweeted it is “Very important that OPEC increase the flow of Oil. World Markets are fragile, price of Oil getting too high.”. In other news, US President Trump is to issue Executive Order to speed up pipeline development. (Twitter)

Russian Energy Minister Novak reportedly told Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih that he cannot guarantee an extension of oil output cuts until the end of the year according to sources, while the report suggests that OPEC and Russian could agree to a 3-month extension of the current agreement at the June meeting. (Newswires)

US has instructed foreign trading firms and refiners to stop direct and indirect oil swap deals with Venezuela and warned a continuation would be seen as a sanction breach according to sources. Furthermore, reports added that only deliveries of jet fuel and diesel can continue for humanitarian reasons, while the US government reportedly asked OPEC behind closed doors to remove Venezuelan official from OPEC presidency. (Newswires) 

A number of Libyan oil ports were shut due to bad weather according to a port agent. (Newswires)

CME lowered May 2019 NYMEX crude oil futures margins by 8.1% to USD 3400 per contract and raised NYMEX palladium futures margins by 25% to USD 10313 per contract. (Newswires)

US

Fed's Williams (voter, hawk) said the US economy is in a very good place and there is a reality it is slowing but to a sustainable pace. Williams also commented that he is not as worried about the chances of a recession as some in the private sector and stated that the yield curve inversion has historically pointed to a recession but that may not be the case today, while he also doesn't believe governments can run large deficits indefinitely without consequences. (Newswires)

Fed's Clarida (voter, neutral) said the Fed must pay ever closer attention to global growth risks and that it can be patient amid global risks and muted inflation. Furthermore, Clarida also commented that first response would be traditional policy if we have an adverse shock to the economy. (WSJ)

US GDP Final Q4 2.2% vs. Exp. 2.4% (Prev. 2.6%). (Newswires)

MARKET RECAP

Accenture (ACN) outperformed on Thursday after beating earnings estimates and providing optimistic  guidance. Nielsen (NLSN) nosedived after the Blackstone Group (BX) withdrew its buyout offer. Lululemon (LULU) surged to record levels on the back of stellar earnings guidance. PVH Corp (PVH) also made large gains after strong guidance. Amarin (AMRN) caught a bid on the back of the American Diabetes Association commenting positively on its fish oil treatment. Wabco (WBC) sold off sharply after it agreed to sell itself to a German competitor. Five Below (FIVE) surged on beating earnings estimates. Ford (F) traded higher after it was announced it would be collaborating with Volkswagen on a truck. Western Digital (WDC) benefitted from an Outperform initiation at RBC. A weak US Pending Home Sales data release saw homebuilders (LEN, PHM, DHI TOL) take a dip. Sprint (S) underperformed following reports it said it would suffer without the T-Mobile (TMUS) merger. SPX +0.36% at 2815, NDX +0.17% at 7320, DJI +0.36% at 25717.

The curve was mixed at settlement, with 2s5s a touch steeper, though other major curve spreads narrowed (5s30s by as much as 5bps). There was optimism about US/China trade talks, which saw some flattening in European trade. Treasuries took some influence from the Bund after German inflation was short of expectations. There was little reaction after data showed US GDP in Q4 was revised lower. The Treasury's 7s auction was decent, stopping through by 0.9bps, with cover above recent averages; there was reported short-covering after the auction. Fed's Williams -- like the Fed's Daly earlier in the week -- suggested that the yield curve inversion might not necessarily portend a recession; previously some FOMC members have argued that the size of the Fed's balance sheet makes presents challenges for this signal as portending a recession. RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 28 March 2019: Trade optimism as US-China talks continue in Beijing
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

US MARKET WRAP 28 March 2019: Trade optimism as US-China talks continue in Beijing

 

* SNAP SHOT: Equities up, dollar up, treasuries down, crude down.

* REAR VIEW: China makes pro-foreign tech offers, but no IP breakthrough; US Q4 GDP revised lower; Pending Home Sales surprises lower; PM May’s WA to be voted on tomorrow; Russia sceptical on sustaining oil cuts; Trump vs. oil prices

* AHEAD: German Retail Sales & Unemployment Data, UK GDP, Italian CPI (Prelim), US Consumption & PCE Price Index, US Chicago PMI & New Home Sales, Canadian GDP, Fed's Williams & Quarles, ECB's Coeure, US-China trade talks continue in Beijing

 

* TRADE: As high-level trade talks kick-off in Beijing, WSJ reported that China are reportedly offering foreign technology firms better access to China’s fast-growing cloud-computing market. The plan is part of a package of offers on technology-related issues Chinese negotiators are expected to discuss with their U.S. counterparts during the meetings scheduled for Friday. The article went on to specify that under the proposal, foreign providers would be able to own data centres as part of a pilot in a free-trade zone. However, China's Premier Li said that China must protect IP, a key area which the US wants to gain concessions on, to support China's transformation, adding that he does not think there is trust deficit between the US and China, hinting at a potential impasse from the negotiations; US administration officials had said previously that progress in all areas of trade talks had been made but enforcement and IP remain sticking points. Today also saw NEC Director Larry Kudlow make some comments, where he said that some, but not all, China tariffs may remain, and that the trade talks are not time dependent, suggesting that the US is in no rush to come to an agreement after having already postponed potential dates for a signing of a conclusive deal. Separately, Kudlow also said that Trump may take longer to consider the auto-tariff report, a case for implementing tariffs on European automakers which Commerce Secretary Ross submitted to him, a measure that if implemented would be sure to put a damp in US-EU relations.

* FED: Fed's Clarida (voter) said the Fed must pay ever closer attention to global growth risks, and it can be patient amid global risks and muted inflation. Clarida also said that if the US economy saw an adverse shock, its first response would be to use traditional policy tools (rates). Fed's Williams (voter) said the US economy was in a good place, but there was a reality that the economy was slowing, but back to a sustainable pace. Williams seemed unconcerned about suggestions of recession in the future, arguing that while an inverted Treasury curve pointed to recession, it might not be the case today (in the past, the Fed has often said that inversion signals may not mean the same as they have in previous economic cycles, given that the Fed's balance sheet holdings may distort the picture). Williams added that if the economy veered from the Fed's objectives, it would be a reason to rethink the policy path.

* US GDP: Final US GDP for Q4 was revised down from 2.6% to 2.2%, below the expected 2.4% and feeding the narrative that the world’s number one economy is losing steam; however YoY growth for 2018 was still a strong 3%, “something that virtually any other developed market would desperately love to have,” analyst at ING Economics taunt. Looking into the sub-components, consumption, investment and government spending were all revised lower, but net exports were revised higher, breaking the trend, due to fewer imports. Wells Fargo Economics forecast “further deceleration in the first quarter, but… then look for a modest rebound starting in Q2.” The Atlanta Fed GDPNow for Q1 is currently supporting a fading growth stance, where it raised to 1.5% (prev. 1.3%) on the back of Wednesday’s trade figures, albeit still a decline from Q4; participants will be paying close attention to how soft data plays out in the months ahead.

* US PENDING HOME SALES: February’s Pending Home Sales fell by 1%, a tad under the expected 0.7% increase, and a reversal from January’s 4.3% jump, but more broadly, “the downward trend of last year appears to have been broken,” Pantheon Macroeconomics’ analysts note, “Activity was sharply depressed in 2018 by the capping of state and local tax deductions, but perhaps a new, lower equilibrium now has been reached.”

* BREXIT: Wednesday evening in London saw all eight proposed Brexit motions failing to meet a majority, highlighting the complete fracture amongst MPs on how exactly they would like the UK to leave the EU (if at all). It was reported today that another vote will be held tomorrow, this time a government motion where MPs will vote on the withdrawal agreement from PM May’s deal; note however that this is not the anticipated Meaningful Vote 3, which would be a vote on both the WA and the political declaration. HoC speaker Bercow approved the vote, citing that the motion may be voted on as the WA shows differences this time around in comparison to the previous Meaningful Vote 2. If approved by parliament, UK government sources say that the WA would meet the EU’s conditions for an extension of Article 50 to May 22nd; conversely, if the motion is rejected, or if things “fall apart”, ministers were privately suggesting a general election will be held. Following this newsflow, it was reported a senior EU official spoke positively on the developments, saying, “only the withdrawal agreement is a must have for the orderly withdrawal. The political declaration is a nice to have,” showing the possibility of a May 22nd Brexit, but of course this is all highly subject to change.

* SARB REVIEW: The South African Reserve Bank left rates unchanged at 6.75%, as was expected, but the central bank's statement was relatively dovish, leading analysts to believe that its next rate move could be a cut (perhaps in the early part of 2020). Money markets seem to have given a nod to this thinking, and no longer see any rate hikes, though it is yet to price in any cuts over the next year. The governor himself sounded dovish, and policymakers - like other major central banks - are focussed on risks to the growth outlook. The SARB is also paying attention to the ECB and Fed, which have pivoted dovish this year, which has the possibility of seeing a relative tightening in SA. Also, similar to the Fed, the SARB seems as though it will look through inflation risks; the governor sees risks as "balanced" now, after previously seeing them as "moderately to the upside".

* BANXICO: The Mexican central bank held benchmark rates unchanged at 8.25%, in an unanimous decision. It stated that the balance of risks to growth was tilted towards the downside, and inflation risks had an upward bias, amid an environment of marked uncertainty. The central bank also said that medium an long-term macro risks mean it is important that the govt meets its fiscal targets set out in the 2019 budget. The central bank will be paying special attention to uncertainty, pass-through of FX on prices, as well as relative monetary policy with the Fed.

* WTI (K9) SETTLED USD 0.11 LOWER AT USD 59.30/BBL; BRENT (K9) SETTLED USD 0.01 LOWER AT USD 67.82/BBL. Crude prices continued to sell off on Thursday, pressured by global growth concerns, a potentially less-compliant Russia, as well as Trump attempting to jawbone prices lower. Profit-taking continued on the back of US Q4 final GDP being revised lower to 2.2%, as well as underwhelming inflation data out of Germany. Oil futures took a leg lower after Trump tweeted "very important that OPEC increase the flow of Oil. World Markets are fragile, price of Oil getting too high," renewing his criticism of high oil prices, similar to a few weeks back; analysts note that Trump's playbook of calling out high oil prices usually comes when prices are near highs, although the efficacy of his critiques are less pronounced than they have been in the past. Elsewhere, Russian Energy Minister Novak reportedly told Saudi energy minister Al-Falih that he cannot guarantee an extension of the production cuts until the end of the year, and he reportedly went on to say a 3-mopnth extension from the June meeting could be agreed upon. Analysts at Citi said "in addition to the downside pressure from doubts regarding Russian supply restraint, we also see book squaring as a factor ahead of Friday contract expirations in May Brent crude oil, April heating oil, and April RBOB gasoline."

* SPX +0.36% at 2815, NDX +0.17% at 7320, DJI +0.36% at 25717. SECTORS: Energy +0.37%, Materials +0.95%, Industrials +0.77%, Cons Discretionary +0.58%, Cons Staples +0.42%, Healthcare +0.26%, Financials +0.83%, Tech +0.38%, Telecoms -0.50%, Utilities -1.25%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Accenture (ACN) outperformed on Thursday after beating earnings estimates and providing optimistic  guidance. Nielsen (NLSN) nosedived after the Blackstone Group (BX) withdrew its buyout offer. Lululemon (LULU) surged to record levels on the back of stellar earnings guidance. PVH Corp (PVH) also made large gains after strong guidance. Amarin (AMRN) caught a bid on the back of the American Diabetes Association commenting positively on its fish oil treatment. Wabco (WBC) sold off sharply after it agreed to sell itself to a German competitor. Five Below (FIVE) surged on beating earnings estimates. Ford (F) traded higher after it was announced it would be collaborating with Volkswagen on a truck. Western Digital (WDC) benefitted from an Outperform initiation at RBC. A weak US Pending Home Sales data release saw homebuilders (LEN, PHM, DHI TOL) take a dip. Sprint (S) underperformed following reports it said it would suffer without the T-Mobile (TMUS) merger.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLE 6 TICKS LOWER AT 124-16. The curve was mixed at settlement, with 2s5s a touch steeper, though other major curve spreads narrowed (5s30s by as much as 5bps). There was optimism about US/China trade talks, which saw some flattening in European trade. Treasuries took some influence from the Bund after German inflation was short of expectations. There was little reaction after data showed US GDP in Q4 was revised lower. The Treasury's 7s auction was decent, stopping through by 0.9bps, with cover above recent averages; there was reported short-covering after the auction. Fed's Williams -- like the Fed's Daly earlier in the week -- suggested that the yield curve inversion might not necessarily portend a recession; previously some FOMC members have argued that the size of the Fed's balance sheet makes presents challenges for this signal as portending a recession.

* FX WRAP: USD rose, with traders suggesting it may have been a function of dovish signs from other central banks. The USD continued to rise after the Q4 GDP was revised lower. EUR's weakness was attributed to Wednesday's report that the ECB is considering a tiered-approach to rates, with analysts suggesting it is a sign the central bank wants to keep rates lower for longer, while ensuring the stability of the banking sector. The Antipodes have struggled, amid the recently dovish RBNZ, expectations that the same could follow from the RBA, while global growth concerns weigh. In havens, traders are on the watch for SNB intervention with EURCHF sub-1.12, a level that the central bank has intervened in previously; SNB's Maechler reiterated the SNB's policy stance in comments today, while again reminding us it is prepared to intervene in FX. Brexit limbo, and the prospect of UK PM May facing another defeat on Friday left GBP around 1% lower. EMFX was firm, with the BRL an outperformer, trading up on optimism about pension reform. The ZAR was flattish, ahead of tomorrow's rating review at Moody's. TRY was slammed, however, as liquidity returned to the offshore markets, and President's Erdogan's attempts to prevent selling action putting him on collision course with investors and markets. Gold was lower, though most of hte focus was on palladium, which dropped on concerns around global growth and technical factors. Meanwhile, the CNH was flat as USTR Lighthizer and Tsy Sec Mnuchin head to Beijing for trade talks.

Daily FX Wrap: DXY comfortably sits above 97.000 whilst the TRY loses composure
content:
DXY

A solid day of gains for the broad dollar and index (so far) amidst declining US Treasury yields. The index extended gains above 97.000, benefiting from the overall weakness in its G10 and EM pairs and also possibly with the aid of better-than-forecast jobless claims. DXY traded within a 96.82-97.29 band but with a few of Fed speak still ahead with voter Williams set to speak twice ahead of the US close. Note: USTR Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin are to start high level trade talks in Beijing tonight ahead of a full day of dialogue tomorrow. 

GBP, EUR

Sterling the marked underperformer amidst the seemingly never-ending Brexit debacle. The parliamentary timetable is changing on a day-by-day basis, with the latest reports stating the PM May has decided to put the Withdrawal Agreement alone to a Commons vote tomorrow, without the Political Declaration. Nevertheless, House Speaker Bercow will ultimately decide, although ministers are confident that he will agree, as it is said to be different to MV2. GBP/USD has thus far fluctuated within a relatively wide 1.3076-3208 range having briefly dipped below its 50 DMA at 1.3086. Elsewhere, disappointing German regional CPIs set the stage for a national forecast miss, in turn pressuring the single currency, with EUR/USD breaching through chart support at 1.1241, having traded within a 50-pip intraday range (1.1214-64). Participants will be eyeing tomorrow’s German retail sales and unemployment and potential comments from ECB’s Coeure for more direction on the economy.

SEK, NOK, CAD

Not the best start to the day for the Scandi Crowns, although the NOK and SEK have pared back a bulk of the losses as risk sentiment improved. EUR/NOK and EUR/SEK are poised to end European trade closer to the bottom of their respective intraday ranges with the former having fluctuated within a 9.7020-7465 band (having briefly breached its 50 and 100 DMAs at 9.7233 and 9.7373), whilst the latter is set to end the day around its 50 DMA at 10.4558 (having traded within a 10.4250-5050 range). Elsewhere the Loonie was largely dictated by price action in the energy complex and is set to end the European session little changed above 1.3400 vs. the greenback ahead of Canadian GDP tomorrow.

JPY, CHF

A turnaround in risk sentiment has prompted marginal weakness in the safe-haven FX pairs with USD/JPY poised to end EU trade closer to the top of its intraday range of 110.03-82 ahead of last week’s high of 110.96. Similarly, USD/CHF remains above its 100 DMA at 0.9965 and briefly breached 0.9970 to the upside heading into the EU close.

TRY, ZAR, BRL

Another troubled day for the Turkish Lira despite the London swap rate returning to 25% (vs. 1200% yesterday) and the CBRT raising total TRY swap rate to 30% (Prev. 20%) for swap transactions that have not matured. The Lira is set to end EU trade with losses in excess of 4% against the Greenback which followed verbal intervention from Turkish President Erdogan as he piled pressured on the Central Bank to cut interest rates to “deal with inflation”, although the imprisonment of the US consulate worker in Turkey does not bode well for the Turkish currency following its demise the last time a US citizen was detained.

Elsewhere, the South African Central Bank unanimously stood pat on its repo rate at 6.75% as expected. The rand was little changed in the immediate aftermath of the decision despite the downgrades in 2019/2020 GDP forecasts alongside 2020/2021 inflation expectations (2019 inflation forecasts were maintained), weakness was mostly attributed to the rise in the Buck although downside in the ZAR coincided with reports that state-owned Eskom suspended operations in the Garankuwa region amid protests. Note: Moody’s is set to review South Africa’s credit rating tomorrow with some expecting an adjustment.

Finally, BRL remained the outperforming EM currency despite its central bank downgrading GDP forecast to 2% (Prev. 2.4%) as the currency takes its cue from the optimistic developments in pension reforms. The country’s President noted today that the reforms are moving ahead as planned whilst the central bank governor stated he is confident the pension reforms will be approved. Hence the Brazilian Real trades around 0.5% firmer against the Greenback.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 28th March 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European Indices [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.3%] have gained some traction, diverging from the mostly negative performance seen in Asia – for reference, 2 of China’s Big 4 banks have now posted earnings
  • US-China trade talks progress; IP and enforcement remain sticking points
  • No majority for any Brexit indicative option & DUP are to oppose PM May’s deal
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German National CPI (Prelim), US GDP (Final) & Initial Jobless Claims, Japanese Tokyo CPI & Retail Sales, Industrial Output & Unemployment Rate, Fed's Quarles, Clarida, Bostic, Williams & Bullard, ECB's Knot & Villeroy, RBNZ's Orr, Supply from the US

 

ASIA  

Asian equity markets traded mostly negative as the downbeat sentiment rolled over from US where all major indices finished lower amid lingering growth concerns and as the yield curve inversion deepened. As such, ASX 200 (+0.7%) opened subdued but with losses eventually pared by resilience across nearly all sectors, while Nikkei 225 (-1.6%) underperformed and briefly slipped below the 21000 level with selling exacerbated by a firmer currency and rotation into bonds. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.9%) were also cautious with weakness in financials due to earnings in which China’s 2nd largest lender China Construction Bank missed on FY net forecasts and posted its first quarterly Y/Y profit decline since 2015 which doesn’t bode well for the other Big 4 banks to report this week, while China Life Insurance also posted a near-65% drop in FY net. Nonetheless, sentiment in China slightly improved as US and China senior trade negotiators began the latest round of trade talks in Beijing and a Trump administration official suggested progress was made in all areas of trade talks but some sticking points remained. Finally, 10yr JGBs were supported by the negative risk tone in Japan and amid the recent bond market rally as global yields declined in which the US 10yr yield fell to a fresh 15-month low and the Aussie 3yr yield printed its lowest on record, while the results of today’s 2yr auction were also bullish as all metric improved from the prior month, albeit marginally.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7263 (Prev. 6.7141)

Chinese Premier Li said world economy faces slower growth and increasing uncertainties, while he added that some fluctuation in quarterly economic growth this year cannot be ruled out. Chinese Premier Li further commented that China must achieve goal of tax and fee cuts this year, while it will also publish a revised negative list for foreign investors and will treat domestic and foreign companies equally.. Separately, adding that changes in their economy in March have exceeded expectations, adds that China's economic operations were steady in Q1. (Newswires)

US administration official said US and China made progress in all areas of trade talks but enforcement and intellectual property remain sticking points, while China was also said to have made proposals on trade including tech transfers that are more specific and with wider scope than ever before. However, the official added that there is no specific timeframe for a trade deal with talks to conclude anytime from April-June and whether to lift current US tariffs on China is a sticking point and will be worked out as part of a deal. Subsequently, Chinese Premier Li said China must protect IP to support China's transformation, adding that he does not think there is a trust deficit between US and China (Newswires)

China Commerce Ministry says both sides have made progress in talks but there is still work to do. Vice Premier Lui He, USTR Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin are to hold talks tonight followed by a full day of talks tomorrow. (Newswires)

US

Fed's George (Voter, Hawk) said Fed can take a wait-and-see approach on monetary policy given notable downside risks to the economy and that medium-term risks to the economy is from slower growth in China, EU and UK. Fed’s George also commented the Fed is not using balance sheet as a policy tool and does not discuss balance sheet run-off as ‘tightening policy’, while she expects a rebound in payrolls for March and added that US economic growth is likely to slow to 2.0% this year as fiscal and monetary stimulus fades and amid slower global growth. (Newswires)

UK/EU   

UK MPs voted (441 vs. 105) to approve the Statutory Instrument which amends the date of the UK’s withdrawal from the EU to May 22nd if PM May’s Brexit deal passes this week or to April 12th if deal is not approved.

UK Parliamentary indicative votes results showed no majority was reached for any of the Brexit options, although (J)(234 For vs. 272 Against) which compels the government to negotiate for a permanent and comprehensive UK-wide customs union with the EU, and (M)(268 For vs. 295 Against) which called for a second ‘confirmatory’ referendum, were the options that lost by the narrowest margins. (Newswires)

ERG head Jacob Rees-Mogg initially said he will back PM May’s deal if the DUP abstain but later commented he would support the DUP if it continues to oppose the deal. (Newswires/Twitter)

DUP said it will not support the government on the Brexit deal if it tables a 3rd meaningful vote and that the party cannot agree to anything which threatens the union, while DUP's Dodds also said we will vote against PM May's deal and will not abstain when it comes to the union. Subsequetly, DUP Leader Foster has declined to rule out supporting a softer Brexit ahead of talks with the government today. (Newswires)

Former Brexit Secretary Raab said the UK government should return to the EU to seek legally binding changes, if not then UK should prepare for a no-deal Brexit. (Newswires)

Germany's BGA says they expect exports to grow by up to 3% in 2019 at a record high of EUR 1.4tln, imports expected to surpass exports with exp. growth of 5% in 2019; critiqus the shift towards a more interventionalist industrial strategy saying, ‘china light’ policies are not an option. (Newswires)

German Saxony State CPI YY Mar 1.4% (Prev. 1.4%)

German Saxony State CPI MM Mar 0.5% (Prev. 0.3%)

- Saxony State CPI’s came in broadly in-line with expecatiation, with the MM figure marginally higher than the prior. For reference, other German State’s CPI printed largely in-line/marginally below expectations; ahead of the German CPI (Prelim) figure today at 13:00GMT/09:00EDT, where expectations are for MM 0.6% vs. Prev. 0.4% & YY1.6% vs. Prev. 1.5%.

EQUITIES

Major European indices have gained some traction following a subdued start to the session [Eurostoxx 50 +0.2%] as the region diverges from the downbeat sentiment experienced in Asia. UK’s FTSE 100 (+0.6%) outperforms its peers as the weaker domestic currency bolsters the export-heavy index. Sector-wise, material stocks lead the gains as base metals benefit from recent turnaround in the risk sentiment whilst utility names lag as investors move away from defensive sectors. In terms of notable movers, Swedbank (-3.7%) shares took another hit amid the slew of open investigations in relation to money laundering. As the bank’s AGM gets underway, it announced that CFO Anders Karlsson has replaced Birgitte Bonnesen as acting President and CEO.  Company shares are halted until further notice. Elsewhere, chip names remain pressured in a continuation of yesterday’s sell-off after DAX-listed Infineon (-1.1%) announced a profit warning due to rising global tensions.

China Construction Bank (939 HK) - Co. FY18 net rose 5.1% Y/Y to CNY 254.7bln vs. Exp. CNY 258.2bln, Q4 net CNY 40.55bln vs. Prev. CNY 41.02bln Y/Y which was its first decline in quarterly profit since 2015. (Newswires)

ICBC (1398 HK) 2018 net profiit CNY 297.68bln vs. Exp. CNY 300.4bln, Operating income CNY 725.1bln vs. Prev. CNY 675.7bln, NPL ratio 1.52%, capital adequacy ratio 12.98%, net interest margin 2.3% vs. Prev. 2.22%

FX

JPY/NZD - The best G10 performers, albeit off best levels as the Usd retains a firm underlying bid in its own right as a safe-haven amidst a tentative and intermittent revival in broad risk appetite. Usd/Jpy is holding above 110.00 within a 110.03-53 range having tested bids/support just ahead of the big figure where decent option expiry interest resides (1 bn) and is back above daily chart resistance between 110.07-12, while Eur/Jpy has also rebounded from sub-124.00 lows and heavy Japanese selling that pushed the cross down through a key Fib (123.81) at one stage. Meanwhile, the Kiwi has regained some composure after its post-RBNZ rout to reclaim 0.6800 status, but Nzd/Usd remains vulnerable following a marked deterioration in NZ business sentiment and expectations according to ANZ’s March survey, which provides more justification for the change in rate guidance towards an ease vs a neutral stance previously. Note, RBNZ Governor Orr is due to orate later on the new framework for monetary policy.

AUD/EUR - Also weathering a bout of downside pressure relatively well, as the Aussie keeps tabs on the 0.7100 handle vs its US counterpart and remains above 1.0400 against the Nzd, however Aud/Usd could be hampered by a 1 bn expiry ahead of the NY cut along with dovish positioning for next week’s RBA on the notion that the balance of risks could shift towards cutting benchmark rates from a balanced prognosis at present, ala the RBNZ. Meanwhile, the single currency succumbed to spill-over Jpy cross sales vs the Usd that forced the headline pair through recent lows and chart support (at 1.1241), but not much further as it consolidates back above the 76.4% Fib retracement of the 1.1177-1.1448 move.

GBP/SEK/NOK/CAD/CHF - All lagging their major peers, and especially the Pound, Swedish and Norwegian Crowns. Cable has fallen below a fairly resilient 1.3150 mark following the latest UK Parliamentary votes on Brexit ended with no majority support for any of the 8 options tabled, and in fact resounding rejection in 6 instances, leaving the situation even more uncertain than it was before the HoC took the baton from PM May. Meanwhile, Eur/Nok and Eur/Sek have both bounced further in wake of yesterday’s worse than expected Norwegian jobs data and as Swedbank suffers more investor angst over money laundering allegations, with the former up to 9.7465 and latter at 10.4935 before easing back. The Loonie is also weaker post-data, between 1.3400-30 vs its US rival, with the Franc still somewhat mixed as it pivots 0.9950 vs the Greenback and 1.1200 against the Euro in advance of a speech from SNB’s Maechler that could fan speculation about intervention to curb excess Chf strength/demand.

DXY - The index has climbed into a higher range after recent declines amidst falling US Treasury yields and deeper curve inversion to probe above 97.000, and from a technical perspective the Buck may be able to overcome residual month end flows that are said to be mildly bearish.

Brazil’s Economy Minister Guedes said that if the pension reform bill of BRL 1tln passes, interest rates would naturally decline by 2 percentage points. (Newswires)

New Zealand ANZ Business Confidence (Mar) -38.0 (Prev. -30.9). (Newswires) New Zealand ANZ Activity Outlook (Mar) 6.3 (Prev. 10.5)

FIXED INCOME

The 10 year German debt future has seen more downside price action and bullish correction after its mid-week propulsion to new contract peaks and multi-year yield lows, with a pull-back to 166.28 effectively matching another near term chart support level at 166.31, but not triggering stops that might have resulted in a deeper retracement (to 166.19, which represents 50% of Wednesday’s rally). However, Bunds are still underperforming Gilts and US Treasuries as the UK benchmark rebounds firmly to eke out a marginal new Liffe high at 129.54 from a fresh base (129.18) and the latter trade just a fraction below par ahead of a busy data line up and the final leg of this week’s supply in the form of Usd32 bn 7 year notes. Back to Eurex, consolidation and unwinding some outperformance appears more evident than a decisive change of direction or trend, but a loss of momentum could also be attributed to the bulk of month end positioning already done (to recap, durations are said to be supportive for Eurozone bonds, and Gilts).

COMMODITIES

WTI (-0.6%) and Brent (-0.6%) futures languish following yesterday’s pullback, although the benchmarks remain off worst levels amid an improvement in market sentiment. Despite this week’s builds in API and DoE crude inventories (API +1.9mln, DoE +2.8mln), UBS analysts note that both weekly data and for the year thus far are more bullish than usual. Meanwhile, WSJ reported that Saudi Aramco plans to issue a USD 10bln bond, to be used as part of a payment for their 70% purchase of Sabic which is valued at USD 69.1bln, according to sources. On the OPEC+ front, Russian Energy Minister Novak told RIA newspaper that the OPEC+ Charter could be signed in either May or June. Elsewhere, precious metals are pressured by firmer buck with gold (-0.2%) hovering close to its 50 DMA at 1307/oz. Meanwhile, base metals are faring better, with risk-gauge copper bouncing off lows as the risk appetite supports the red metal.

subject: Bunds: off overnight highs ahead of data, more ECB speak and month end
content: Some signs of consolidation and a loss of momentum after the 10 year German benchmark recovered from a modest initial markdown and wobble to trade a little further below parity at 166.47 vs Wednesday’s 166.59 close before rebounding to 166.75 at best. However, the pull-back seems more technical rather than fundamental with chart gaps left following yesterday’s spikes through 166.00 and beyond that tripped stops and all round buying. Bunds subsequently drifted down to a minor new Eurex low at 166.39, but are paring some losses into the EU cash equity opens, data and ahead of another raft of ECB speakers.

SSE (SSE LN) – Co. expects to deliver a FY 18/19 dividend of GBP 0.975/shr. (Newswires)

Dignity (DTY LN) – UK CMA has launched an in-depth investigation into the Funerals sector, as the CMA are concerned regarding the sectors effectiveness regarding competition; the investigation is to focus on supply of services by funeral directors and crematoriums. CMA’s concerns are highlighted by the observation that funeral organisation costs have rise by 6% Y/Y for the last 14 years. (Newswires)

Lufhansa (LHA GY) – German Air Traffic Control says the software problems at Langen control centre have been fixed. Traffic restrictions were lifted as of 0300GMT. (Newswires)

Taylor Wimpey (TW/ LN) – Co. have announced directorate changes, with Legal Director & Co. Secretary to retire, and the appointment of General Council & Co. Secretary. (Newswires)

Scout24 (G24 GY) – Hellman & Friedman and Blackstone has offered EUR 46.00/shr in cash for Co. Acceptance period will be from March 28th to May 9th. (Newswires)

Daimler (DAI GY) - Co. and Geely are to build electric smart vehicles in China, with sales to begin in 2022. Terms of JV to be finalised by 2019 end. Co. says the smart factory is Hambach, France will switch production to Mercedes-Benz cars. (Newswires)

Swedbank (SWEDA SS) - Sweden's Economic Crime Authority have expanded their preliminary investigation into the Co. to include the potential for aggravated fraud. Separately, investor Alecta & Folksam say they will vote against granting the CEO freedom from liability for 2018  (Newswires). For reference the Co. have their AGM today.

subject: China Commerce Ministry says both sides have made progress in talks but there is still work to do. Vice Premier Lui He, USTR Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin are to hold talks tonight followed by a full day of talks tomorrow
DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

28th March 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0200CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0200CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0215CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0250CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0215CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly negative as the downbeat sentiment rolled over from US where all major indices finished lower amid lingering growth concerns and as the yield curve inversion deepened. As such, ASX 200 (+0.7%) opened subdued but with losses eventually pared by resilience across nearly all sectors, while Nikkei 225 (-1.6%) underperformed and briefly slipped below the 21000 level with selling exacerbated by a firmer currency and rotation into bonds. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) were also cautious with weakness in financials due to earnings in which China’s 2nd largest lender China Construction Bank missed on FY net forecasts and posted its first quarterly Y/Y profit decline since 2015 which doesn’t bode well for the other Big 4 banks to report this week, while China Life Insurance also posted a near-65% drop in FY net. Nonetheless, sentiment in China slightly improved as US and China senior trade negotiators began the latest round of trade talks in Beijing and a Trump administration official suggested progress was made in all areas of trade talks but some sticking points remained.

FTSE

Ex-Divs – British Land (BLND LN), InterContinental Hotels (IHG LN), Prudential (PRU LN), and Schroders (SDR LN) will trade without entitlement to their latest dividend pay-out on Thursday, trimming 4.5 points off the FTSE 100. (Newswires)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – Co.’s chairman stated that the group is concerned about the China slowdown, however the Co. has not been affected. (Newswire)

BHP (BHP LN) – Co. is reportedly mulling a bid for Bluewater which is backed by Blackstone. (Newswires) 

GVC Holdings (GVC LN) – Co. CEO Alexander promised he will not sell any more shares while he remains in his position. This comes after the CEO spooked investors earlier this month following his sale of over 2mln shares. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

METRO BANK (MTRO LN) INITIATED UNDERWEIGHT AT BARCLAYS

DAX

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Co. is considering cutting costs following a weak Q1, according to Handelsblatt citing sources. (Handelsblatt)

Bayer (BAYN GY) – US jury said Co. must pay USD 80mln to a man who claimed Co.’s weedkiller caused his cancer. (FT)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Hochtief (HOT GY) – Atlantia (ATL IM) said it will sell 4.35mln of its Hochtief shares to institutional investors via block trade to remove downside exposure and allow Atlantia to repay part of its outstanding debt. (Newswires)

1&1 Drillisch (DRI GY) – FY revenue +30.2% to EUR 3.66bln. Adj. EBITDA +35.6% to EUR 721.9mln. Co. expects continued strong growth in customer numbers. (Newswires) 

United Internet (UTDI GY) – FY sales +22% to EUR 5.13bln. EBITDA +22.6% to EUR 1.201bln. Co. expects 2019 sales growth of around 4%, EBITDA growth of around 8%. (Newswires)

Evotec (EVT GY) – FY revenue EUR 375.4mln vs. Exp. EUR 364.0mln. EBITDA EUR 95.5mln vs. Exp. 85.1mln. Co. expects revenue and EBITDA increase of around 10%. Co. currently has no plans to distribute dividends. (Newswires) 

Baywa (BYW GY) – FY sales EUR 16.6bln vs. Prev. EUR 16.1bln. FY EBIT EUR 172.4mln vs. Prev. EUR 171.3mln.  Co. propose a dividend of EUR 0.90 vs. Prev. EUR 0.90 per share. Co. see significantly better earnings in Q1 vs. prior year. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

BAYER (BAYN GY) INITIATED BUY AT LIBERUM CAPITAL

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 28th March 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian indices were mixed, as the region somewhat diverged from Wall Street’s negative lead – China’s 2nd largest bank posted disappointing earnings, ahead of the other Big 4’s results
  • US-China trade talks progress; IP and enforcement remain sticking points
  • UK PM May lays out resignation path, no majority for any indicative option; while DUP are to oppose PM’s deal
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German State & National CPI (Prelim), US GDP (Final) & Initial Jobless Claims, Japanese Tokyo CPI & Retail Sales, Industrial Output & Unemployment Rate, Fed's Quarles, Clarida, Bostic, Williams & Bullard, ECB's de Guindos, Nowotny, Knot & Villeroy, RBNZ's Orr, Supply from the US & Italy

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly negative as the downbeat sentiment rolled over from US where all major indices finished lower amid lingering growth concerns and as the yield curve inversion deepened. As such, ASX 200 (+0.7%) opened subdued but with losses eventually pared by resilience across nearly all sectors, while Nikkei 225 (-1.6%) underperformed and briefly slipped below the 21000 level with selling exacerbated by a firmer currency and rotation into bonds. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) were also cautious with weakness in financials due to earnings in which China’s 2nd largest lender China Construction Bank missed on FY net forecasts and posted its first quarterly Y/Y profit decline since 2015 which doesn’t bode well for the other Big 4 banks to report this week, while China Life Insurance also posted a near-65% drop in FY net. Nonetheless, sentiment in China slightly improved as US and China senior trade negotiators began the latest round of trade talks in Beijing and a Trump administration official suggested progress was made in all areas of trade talks but some sticking points remained. Finally, 10yr JGBs were supported by the negative risk tone in Japan and amid the recent bond market rally as global yields declined in which the US 10yr yield fell to a fresh 15-month low and the Aussie 3yr yield printed its lowest on record, while the results of today’s 2yr auction were also bullish as all metric improved from the prior month, albeit marginally.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7263 (Prev. 6.7141)

Chinese Premier Li said world economy faces slower growth and increasing uncertainties, while he added that some fluctuation in quarterly economic growth this year cannot be ruled out. Chinese Premier Li further commented that China must achieve goal of tax and fee cuts this year, while it will also publish a revised negative list for foreign investors and will treat domestic and foreign companies equally. (Newswires)

US administration official said US and China made progress in all areas of trade talks but enforcement and intellectual property remain sticking points, while China was also said to have made proposals on trade including tech transfers that are more specific and with wider scope than ever before. However, the official added that there is no specific timeframe for a trade deal with talks to conclude anytime from April-June and whether to lift current US tariffs on China is a sticking point and will be worked out as part of a deal. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM May told the 1922 committee members that she will hand over leadership once Brexit is delivered. Furthermore, other reports suggested that she will not stay for the next stage of negotiations and others noted that will step down in the summer. (Huffington Post/Daily Mirror/The Guardian/Twitter)

UK MPs voted (441 vs. 105) to approve the Statutory Instrument which amends the date of the UK’s withdrawal from the EU to May 22nd if PM May’s Brexit deal passes this week or to April 12th if deal is not approved.

UK Parliamentary indicative votes results showed no majority was reached for any of the Brexit options, although (J)(234 For vs. 272 Against) which compels the government to negotiate for a permanent and comprehensive UK-wide customs union with the EU, and (M)(268 For vs. 295 Against) which called for a second ‘confirmatory’ referendum, were the options that lost by the narrowest margins. (Newswires)

DUP said it will not support the government on the Brexit deal if it tables a 3rd meaningful vote and that the party cannot agree to anything which threatens the union, while DUP's Dodds also said we will vote against PM May's deal and will not abstain when it comes to the union. (Newswires)

UK ERG source suggested 40 lawmakers have switched to back PM May's deal and 40 are undecided, according to The Times' Sam Coates. Separately, ERG head Jacob Rees-Mogg initially said he will back PM May’s deal if the DUP abstain but later commented he would support the DUP if it continues to oppose the deal, while former Foreign Minister Boris Johnson is also reportedly to back PM May's deal. (Newswires/Twitter)

FX

In FX markets, the DXY remained near its best levels in 2 weeks and continued to eye the 97.00 level to the upside as the cautious risk tone underpinned demand for safe-haven currencies, which was more evident in USD/JPY and JPY-crosses. EUR/USD was uneventful with prices stuck at the 1.1250 level where a large option expiry resides for today’s New York cut and GBP/USD slipped below 1.3200 on Brexit uncertainty. This was as hopes PM May could garner enough support for her Brexit deal after her promise to step down, were eventually dashed by the DUP which will vote against the deal citing a threat to the integrity of the UK, while GBP was further dampened after Parliament voted against all Brexit options in the indicative votes. Antipodeans were initially subdued due to their high-beta characteristics and with NZD/USD also weighed by a further deterioration in Business Surveys but later showed recovered as risk sentiment across the Tasman began to improve. Elsewhere, some EM currencies took a hit with BRL testing 5-month lows amid domestic pension reform concerns and weakness across LATAM, while TRY was also spooked after a crackdown on speculation against the currency resulted in the overnight borrowing rate for the currency in the offshore swap market briefly rocketing past 1000%.

New Zealand ANZ Business Confidence (Mar) -38.0 (Prev. -30.9). (Newswires) New Zealand ANZ Activity Outlook (Mar) 6.3 (Prev. 10.5)

Brazilian President Bolsonaro said his health has impaired his role leading the government and suggested that Brazil will go bankrupt if pension reform is not approved, while Economy Minister Guedes said that if the pension reform bill of BRL 1tln passes, interest rates would naturally decline by 2 percentage points. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were uneventful in which WTI crude futures languished following yesterday’s pullback from the USD 60/bbl level in which growth concerns and a surprise build in this week’s inventory reports weighed on the energy complex. However, losses were limited overnight with support seen around USD 59.00/bbl and amid ongoing supply disruptions with the Houston ship channel likely to experience delays for a few more days and following the recent power outage at Venezuela’s main oil port. Elsewhere, gold was uneventful with the precious metal restricted by a firmer greenback and copper also traded flat amid the mixed overnight risk tone.

Venezuela maintained its four heavy crude upgraders halted from Monday's blackout and workers were reportedly to attempt a restart later on Wednesday, according to sources. (Newswires)

Houston Shipping Channel delays may last 3-5 more days according to an update. (Newswires)

US

Most of the early action overnight/Europe trade was focussed on the short-end, underpinned by comments from Fed governor nominee Moore, who called on the Fed to immediately cut rates by 50bps. This saw the curve bull steepen. There was focus on a German 10yr auction, which sold at negative yields for the first time since 2016.The long-end of the yield curve continued to test new lows (lowest in over a year), with participants continuing to note that the 30-year bucket is the only part of the curve with its head above the effective fed funds rate. On that note, the 3m/10y inversion deepened to over 10bps on Wednesday trade; the market has been rationalising these moves with more circumspection, though concerns about the growth outlook are clearly evident. Next week’s survey data and jobs data may provide the next major catalyst for the narrative to be tweaked. Meanwhile, the belly of the curve saw decent action; in early trade a block sale of the FVM9 in 5k was followed by a large sale (15k); later in the session, some desks had reported real money was profit taking in the belly. US T-note futures (M9) settled 9 ticks higher at 124-22.

Fed's George (Voter, Hawk) said Fed can take a wait-and-see approach on monetary policy given notable downside risks to the economy and that medium-term risks to the economy is from slower growth in China, EU and UK. Fed’s George also commented the Fed is not using balance sheet as a policy tool and does not discuss balance sheet run-off as ‘tightening policy’, while she expects a rebound in payrolls for March and added that US economic growth is likely to slow to 2.0% this year as fiscal and monetary stimulus fades and amid slower global growth. (Newswires)

subject: ASIA-PAC MID SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks trade mostly lower as growth concerns linger amid deeper yield inversion
content:
Asia equity markets are mostly negative with the downbeat sentiment rolling over from the US where all major indices finished lower amid lingering growth concerns and as the yield curve inversion deepened. As such, ASX 200 (+0.3%) opened subdued but with losses eventually pared by resilience in mining names, while Nikkei 225 (-1.6%) underperformed and briefly slipped below the 21000 level with selling exacerbated by a firmer currency and rotation into safety assets. Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) are also weaker with financials underperforming due to earnings in which China’s 2nd largest lender China Construction Bank missed on FY net forecasts and posted its first quarterly Y/Y profit decline since 2015 which doesn’t bode well for the other Big 4 banks to report this week, while China Life Insurance also posted a near-65% drop in FY net. Nonetheless, the losses in the broader market have been stemmed as US and China senior trade negotiators began the latest round of trade talks in Beijing and a Trump administration official suggested progress was made in all areas of trade talks although enforcement and intellectual property remain sticking points.

In FX markets, the DXY remains near its best levels in 2 weeks and continues to eye the 97.00 level to the upside as the negative risk tone underpins demand for safe-haven currencies, which is more evident for the JPY with USD/JPY and JPY-crosses pressured across the board. Elsewhere, EUR/USD is uneventful with prices stuck at the 1.1250 level where a large option expiry resides for today’s New York cut and GBP/USD has slipped below 1.3200 on Brexit uncertainty. This was as hopes of PM May’s Brexit deal passing, following her promise to step down once Brexit is delivered, were eventually dashed by the DUP which will vote against the deal citing a threat to the integrity of the UK, while GBP was further dampened after Parliament voted against all Brexit options in the indicative votes. Antipodeans were initially subdued due to their high-beta characteristics and with NZD/USD also weighed by a further deterioration in Business Surveys but later showed some resilience as risk sentiment across the Tasman began to improve. Elsewhere, some EM currencies have taken a hit with BRL testing 5-month lows amid domestic pension reform concerns and weakness across LATAM, while TRY was also spooked after a crackdown on speculation against the currency resulted in the overnight borrowing rate for the currency in the offshore swap market briefly rocketing past 1000%.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher to track the upside in T-notes as global yields decline in which the US 10yr yield fell to fresh 15-month low and the Aussie 3yr yield at record lows, while focus now turns to a 2yr JGB auction later.
